article.description: Connecticut (No. 2 ESPN/USA Today, No. 3 AP) got 26 points and 10 boards from Diana Taurasi on Friday night and beat Pepperdine 109-48 for its 47th consecutive victory. The Huskies (8-0) were coming off a 12-day break after sloppy wins over Holy Cross and
article.headline: UConn's 47-game streak second in NCAA history
article.linkText: UConn romps past Pepperdine for 47th straight win
article.story:
STORRS, Conn. (AP) -- A little rest went a long way for the defending national champions.

Connecticut (No. 2 ESPN/USA Today, No. 3 AP) got 26 points and 10 boards from Diana Taurasi on Friday night and beat Pepperdine 109-48 for its 47th consecutive victory. The Huskies (8-0) were coming off a 12-day break after sloppy wins over Holy Cross and Southern Cal, a two-game stretch that produced 49 UConn turnovers.

Taurasi, the lone returning starter from last season's title team, quickly put her team on the right track Friday. The junior guard scored 14 straight points in a 23-8 run to open the game, and capped the spurt with back-to-back 3-pointers. She had 21 points in the first half.

``We knew that we needed to pick it up,'' Taurasi said. ``Exams are over, all we have to concentrate on is basketball right now and have fun.''

The Waves (5-4) could do little to stop Taurasi from the opening
tip. She scored easily from the perimeter and baseline, and was
3-for-3 from the foul line. The one person it seemed that could
stop Taurasi was, well, Taurasi.

``The only way we stopped her was when she missed her own shot,'' Pepperdine coach Mark Trakh said. ``We tried four different kids on her. We tried to keep pressure on her all the time, but that really didn't matter.''

The victory also gave UConn, which finished 39-0 last season, the second-longest streak in NCAA history. Louisiana Tech won 54 in a row from 1980-82.

UConn coach Geno Auriemma said the break came just in time for his young team. He gave the team three days off after the USC game.

``So much of what you do is state of mind,'' Auriemma said. ``We were in a poor state of mind. We've had three really good workouts. You could see it getting better every day.''

UConn held Pepperdine to 24 percent shooting in the first half and led 54-20 at the break. The Huskies shot 65 percent in the second half to reach 100 points for the first time this season. They were also more sure-handed, committing just eight turnovers -- all in the first half.

``In the locker room we knew that today was going to be a good
game for us. You could see it in everybody's eyes,'' said forward
Ashley Battle, who returned to the starting lineup after missing
the last game with a sprained left foot.

The Huskies had a big edge on the boards, outrebounding the
Waves 45-31 and outscoring Pepperdine 38-10 in the paint. Jessica
Moore had four of UConn's 11 blocks. The Huskies scored 32 points
off 21 Pepperdine turnovers.

   Taurasi also had seven assists and was 10-of-17 from the field.
Teammate Ann Strother finished with 14 points and Battle had 11.

Shandrika Lee led the Waves with 15 points, and Nicole Funn added 10.
